quoteFirst: We continued running in until we were within musket shot of the crown and mole batteries, when we brought to and fired upwards of three hundred round shot, besides grape and canister, into the town, Bashaw's castle, and batteries. We silenced the castle and two of the batteries for some time. At a
quoteLast: , the gunboats being all out of shot and in tow, I hauled off, after having been three-quarters of an hour in close action. The gunboats fired upwards of four hundred round shot, besides grape and canister, with good effect. A large Tunisian galliot was sunk in the mole.
title: The Medallic History of the United States of America 1776-1876
author: Loubat, J. F. (Joseph Florimond), 1831-1927; Jacquemart, Jules-Ferdinand, 1837-1880 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: After paying the landlord at the George Hotel, we drove to the Broomielaw, where the ship lay alongside the wharf, when we went on board, and at
quoteLast: we sailed with the tide. As we steamed out slowly among the shipping in the harbour, the town of machinery and tall chimneys, out of which interminable serpents of smoke trailed themselves for ever and ever and never got uncoiled, the Clyde, as the tide receded, looked like a river that ran purple with ill-smelling dye, and vast piles of buildings full of windows where there was a rattling and trembling all day long, and where the piston of the steam engine worked monotonously up and down in a state of madness.
title: Stirring Incidents in the Life of a British Soldier: An Autobiography
author: Faughnan, Thomas, active 1835-1883

quoteFirst: Varvilliers pleaded an express appointment with me, and the officer, surprised but conquered, had let them pass. All this Varvilliers told us in his usual airy manner, Wetter sitting apart the while. The clock struck a
title: The King's Mirror
author: Hope, Anthony, 1863-1933

quoteFirst: A few moments later, she was running like a startled hare in the direction of a weak point in the wall which surrounded the Chase enclosure, as she particularly wished to avoid awaking the lodge-keepers from their slumbers. By a
quoteLast: she had reached the inn where Hilary was staying. The window-blinds were all drawn down, and no one was stirring but her friend the hostler, who, whistling an air popular in London some months before, was pottering about the stable-yard.
title: The gray wolf's daughter
author: Warden, Gertrude, 1859-1925

quoteFirst: In the afternoon I walked again to the Falls and round the town. During this walk--as in the morning--I could not get rid of a curious--probably entirely nervous--lassitude, which prevented my full enjoyment of this beautiful scenery. I started again at a

quoteFirst: Chattering women innumerable scurried by on the walk. His dollar watch showed a
quoteLast: in the light from the ticket office window and John counted his papers.
title: A son of the city
author: Seely, Herman Gastrell; Arting, Fred J., 1875-1922 [Illustrator]

quoteLast: , _mon ami_, was the hour fixed--I shudderd! By the way, most of these men were dancing yesterday afternoon till 7-45--at tennis previously, and at bridge till the small hours. Isn't that a rum way of doing things--the ladies dancing till after 7 o'clock, then dashing home to dress, and here at this bungalow to dinner at little after eight.
title: From Edinburgh to India & Burmah
author: Burn Murdoch, W. G. (William Gordon), 1862-1939

quoteFirst: I went to the house pondering these things in my mind, and, arriving there, heard the hall clock strike the quarter, from which I knew it was a
quoteLast: . We were to dine at seven that day, and, as I did not usually make an elaborate toilette, I knew I had plenty of time. I felt I could not go in for a few minutes; my brain seemed on fire.
title: The Weapons of Mystery
author: Hocking, Joseph, 1860-1937
